sect1.title: FlyMine coding standards
sect1.para: This document presents the standards to which all code in the FlyMine project should adhere. These coding standards are intended to ensure that all code is understandable and maintainable by everyone, and that the whole project remains robust and buildable by anyone. All code should follow the Sun Java coding guidelines, but with the following taking precedence.

itemizedlist.listitem: Use English names, eg. startCodon and not sc
Use mixed-case names eg. startCodon and not startcodon.
Attribute and method names should begin with a lowercase character, class names should begin with an upper case character.
Names should be less than 15 characters long
Use getXxx() and setXxx() methods for getting and setting class fields. Boolean fields should have isXxx and setXxx accessors, eg. isPersistent().
Use the minimum visibility level necessary for a method.

All member functions should have JavaDoc comments to include
What and why the function does what it does What the parameters are. The return value. Exceptions. Examples of use, if applicable.
All code must follow normal Java indentation rules with an indent of 4 spaces.
Open curly braces to appear on same line as preceding code, with a gap of one space. The exception to this is after a class definition, where the open curly brace should be on the next line.
Close curly braces to appear on new line by themselves.
Leave one space around operators (eg. if (a == 16) and not if (a==16)).
No line should be longer than 80 characters. Split onto multiple lines if necessary.
Make liberal use of brackets in expressions, even when not necessary. For example, newAmount = (4 * oldAmount) + 17 and not newAmount = 4 * oldAmount + 17.
All revisions to a file must be checked in with a corresponding short comment describing the changes made to that file.
General comments such as Corrected error and Fixed bug should be avoided.
Say what was done to that file, rather than having the same comment on a large number of files committed at the same time.
No paths, usernames, passwords etc to be hardcoded in to the code. Where necessary, these should be in a properties file.

The complete system must build directly out of CVS and not require any external jar files or binaries (apart from Ant and the JDK!!). Any dependent jar files must be in CVS in either the buildlib directory (for jars only needed during the build process) or the lib directory.
Any files no longer used should be removed using the command cvs rm.
Commit little and often.
All classes should have a corresponding JUnit test class (in the tests directory).
Test classes should thoroughly test every public method of the class except getters and setters.
Unit tests are concerned only with inputs and outputs of methods, not the internal workings of the method.
Test class names should be the name of the class being tested, suffixed with the word Test, eg. ClassNameTest.
Test methods names should begin with test, and give an indication of what is being tested eg. testEquals.
Test classes must include tests for declared exceptions and runtime exceptions, and for invalid parameters (eg. null values, empty strings, negative numbers, etc.).
All JUnit tests should pass on code that is checked in to CVS. If you check something in which causes any test to fail, it is your responsibility return the master build to 100% pass rate.
Test classes should be self-contained and not leave any data lingering in the database. Override the setUp() and tearDown() method of the TestCase superclass.
All modules of the system should include some functional tests. These will probably use a set of test data.
Functional tests should view the whole module as a black box.
All logging to be done via log4j. No output messages to be written to stout or sterr.
Make use of the different logging levels available.
Log messages must be descriptive. For example, log.info("Exon count: "+exonCount) and not log.info(exonCount).
